entity1.name: human body
entity1.description: A type of cell in the immune system that defends the body against infectious diseases and foreign invaders.;;;Groups of cells that work together to perform specific functions within an organism, including those involved in the immune system.;;;Disease-causing microorganisms, such as bacteria, viruses, fungi, or parasites.;;;Organisms that live on or in a host organism and get their food from or at the expense of the host.;;;Proteins produced by the immune system to identify and neutralize foreign objects such as bacteria and viruses.;;;A group of proteins that work together to enhance the ability of antibodies to destroy pathogens.;;;A type of white blood cell that produces antibodies as part of the immune system.;;;An invasion of an organism by a pathogen that can cause disease.;;;A biological process that involves the body's defense mechanisms against pathogens and other harmful agents.;;;A group of diseases involving abnormal cell growth with the potential to invade or spread to other parts of the body.;;;An abnormal condition in an organism that impairs bodily functions, often associated with specific symptoms and signs.;;;Disease-causing organisms such as bacteria, viruses, and fungi.;;;Disease-causing organisms such as bacteria, viruses, fungi, or parasites.;;;Cells of the immune system that protect the body against both infectious disease and foreign invaders.;;;A type of white blood cell involved in the specific immune response, including the recognition of foreign substances and the activation of other immune cells.;;;Diseases caused by the invasion of microorganisms such as bacteria, viruses, or fungi into the body.;;;An organism capable of causing disease in a host.;;;A group of metabolic disorders characterized by high blood sugar levels over a prolonged period.;;;Disease-causing organisms such as bacteria, viruses, fungi, and parasites.;;;The reaction of the immune system to a foreign substance, such as a pathogen or toxin, which results in the elimination of the invader and restoration of homeostasis.;;;An invasion of an organism's body tissues by disease-causing agents, their multiplication, and the reaction of body tissues to these organisms and the toxins they produce.;;;A type of white blood cell that is part of the innate immune system, primarily involved in fighting bacterial infections.;;;Structures in the body that prevent pathogens from entering and causing infections.;;;A range of conditions that affect the heart, including coronary artery disease, heart rhythm problems, and congenital heart defects.;;;The entire physical structure of an organism, which is protected by the immune system against infections.;;;A type of white blood cell that is part of the immune system and plays a key role in adaptive immunity.;;;A complex network of cells, tissues, and organs that work together to defend the body against pathogens and other foreign substances.;;;A subtype of lymphocytes responsible for producing antibodies as part of the adaptive immune response.;;;A type of white blood cell that plays a crucial role in the immune response by engulfing and digesting pathogens and cellular debris.;;;Signaling molecules that coordinate the immune response and regulate the activity of immune cells.;;;Structures composed of two or more tissue types that work together to perform specific functions in the body.;;;A prolonged inflammatory response that can cause damage to healthy tissues over time.;;;A type of cell in the immune system that helps to fight infections and diseases.;;;Diseases caused by the invasion and multiplication of pathogenic microorganisms in the body, which the immune response aims to prevent or eliminate.;;;A complex network of cells, tissues, and organs that work together to defend the body against pathogens.;;;The basic structural and functional units of living organisms, which play a crucial role in the immune response.;;;Eukaryotic organisms that include microorganisms such as yeasts and molds, as well as mushrooms.;;;Specialized cells of the immune system that play a role in defending the body against infectious disease and foreign invaders.;;;Infectious agents that are only able to replicate inside the living cells of other organisms.;;;Pathogens are microorganisms that can cause disease. They include bacteria, viruses, fungi, and parasites.;;;A type of white blood cell that plays a central role in cell-mediated immunity and can directly attack infected cells.;;;The processes within an organism that protect against disease by identifying and neutralizing pathogens and tumor cells.;;;Large phagocytic cells found in tissues throughout the body, which play a crucial role in innate immunity by ingesting and destroying pathogens and cellular debris.;;;A microorganism that can cause disease in its host, such as bacteria, viruses, fungi, or parasites.;;;The physical structure of a human, including all its organs and systems.;;;A subset of lymphocytes that have previously encountered a specific antigen and can mount a faster and stronger immune response upon re-exposure to the same antigen.;;;Cells that have been invaded by a pathogen or microorganism, potentially causing disease.;;;Disorders in which the immune system mistakenly attacks and damages the body's own tissues.;;;A complex network of cells, tissues, and organs that work together to identify and eliminate pathogens.;;;The invasion of an organism's body tissues by disease-causing agents, their multiplication, and the reaction of host tissues to these organisms and the toxins they produce.;;;The internal layers of the body beneath the skin.;;;A complex network of cells, tissues, organs, and molecules that work together to defend the body against foreign invaders such as bacteria, viruses, and other pathogens.;;;Microorganisms that can cause disease.;;;The body's defense against infectious organisms and other invaders.;;;A type of white blood cell that is the most abundant and acts as a first responder to infections.;;;Small particles or structures that are essential for various biological processes, including signaling and defense mechanisms in the immune response.;;;A subtype of lymphocytes that play a central role in cell-mediated immunity and can help regulate immune responses.;;;An autoimmune disease where the body's immune system becomes hyperactive and attacks normal, healthy tissue.;;;The outer covering of the body that acts as a protective barrier.;;;Single-celled microorganisms that can exist either as independent organisms or as parasites.;;;The complex network of cells, tissues, organs, and molecules that work together to defend the body against pathogens and other harmful substances.;;;A complex network of cells, tissues, and organs that work together to defend the body against infections and other diseases.;;;Physical structures of the body that prevent pathogens from entering, such as skin and mucous membranes.;;;A type of white blood cell that is part of the adaptive immune system, involved in producing antibodies and mediating specific immune responses.;;;A type of immune cell that can directly kill infected or cancerous cells.;;;Groups of cells that work together to perform a specific function in the body.;;;Disease-causing organisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi, and parasites.;;;Cells are the basic structural and functional units of living organisms. response.;;;The complex and intricate system of the human organism, including all its organs, tissues, and cells.;;;The reaction of the body's immune system to foreign substances, such as pathogens or mounting targeted and specific immune responses.;;;Disease-causing microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi, and parasites.;;;Diseases caused by microorganisms such as bacteria, viruses, trachea, bronchi, and lungs.;;;An organism that can cause disease in other organisms.;;;Disease-causing microorganisms such as bacteria, viruses, fungi, or parasites.;;;Proteins produced by B cells to inflammation in the body that can last for several months or years.;;;A type of white blood cell that is part of the immune system.;;;A complex biological process involving various cellular and with the brain's ability to communicate with the rest of the body.;;;A reaction of the immune system to pathogens or other foreign substances.;;;A group of disorders in which the immune system attacks the body's own tissues, causing damage and dysfunction.

entity22.name: mucous membranes
entity22.description: Tissues lining the body cavities and canals that are exposed to the external environment, such as in the respiratory and digestive tracts.
entity22.chunkid: How the Human Body Fights Infections7

entity24.name: digestive tract
entity24.description: The pathway through which food passes in the body, including the mouth, esophagus, stomach, small intestine, large intestine, and anus.
entity24.chunkid: How the Human Body Fights Infections7

entity25.name: mucus
entity25.description: A slippery secretion produced by mucous membranes that serves to protect and lubricate surfaces in the body.
entity25.chunkid: How the Human Body Fights Infections7

entity27.name: stomach
entity27.description: The muscular, hollow, acid-producing organ of the digestive system that is located in the upper abdomen.
entity27.chunkid: How the Human Body Fights Infections8

entity46.name: phagocytosis
entity46.description: A cellular process by which a cell engulfs and destroys foreign particles or microorganisms.
entity46.chunkid: How the Human Body Fights Infections15

entity76.name: vaccination
entity76.description: The administration of a vaccine to stimulate an individual's immune system to develop adaptive immunity to a pathogen.
entity76.chunkid: How the Human Body Fights Infections27

entity90.name: rheumatoid arthritis
entity90.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet.
entity90.chunkid: How the Human Body Fights Infections34

entity110.name: health
entity110.description: A state of complete physical, mental, and social well-being, not merely the absence of disease or infirmity.
entity110.chunkid: How the Human Body Fights Infections39
